sn47.26:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā ca sāriputto āyasmā ca mahāmoggallāno āyasmā ca anuruddho sākete viharanti kaṇḍakīvane.
sn47.26:1.1.eng: At one time the venerables Sāriputta, Mahāmoggallāna, and Anuruddha were staying near Sāketa, in the Thorny Wood.

sn47.26:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ca sāriputto āyasmā ca mahāmoggallāno sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhitā yenāyasmā anuruddho tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā anuruddhena saddhiṃ sammodiṃsu.
sn47.26:1.2.eng: Then in the late afternoon, Sāriputta and Mahāmoggallāna came out of retreat, went to Anuruddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

sn47.26:1.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā sāriputto āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ etadavoca:
sn47.26:1.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side. Sāriputta said to Anuruddha:

sn47.26:1.4.eng: “Reverend, they speak of the one called ‘a trainee’.

sn47.26:1.5.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, āvuso, sekho hotī”ti?

sn47.26:1.6.pli: “Catunnaṃ kho, āvuso, satipaṭṭhānānaṃ padesaṃ bhāvitattā sekho hoti.
sn47.26:1.6.eng: “Reverends, a trainee is someone who has partly developed the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

sn47.26:2.2.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.26:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.26:2.3.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.26:2.5.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.26:2.5.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.26:2.6.pli: Imesaṃ kho, āvuso, catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ padesaṃ bhāvitattā sekho hotī”ti.
sn47.26:2.6.eng: A trainee is someone who has partly developed the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.”

sn47.27:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā sāriputto āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ etadavoca:

sn47.27:1.3.eng: “Reverend, they speak of the one called ‘an adept’.

sn47.27:1.4.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, āvuso, asekho hotī”ti?

sn47.27:1.5.pli: “Catunnaṃ kho, āvuso, satipaṭṭhānānaṃ samattaṃ bhāvitattā asekho hoti.
sn47.27:1.5.eng: “Reverends, an adept is someone who has completely developed the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

sn47.27:2.2.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.27:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.27:2.3.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.27:2.5.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.27:2.5.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.27:2.6.pli: Imesaṃ kho, āvuso, catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ samattaṃ bhāvitattā asekho hotī”ti.
sn47.27:2.6.eng: An adept is someone who has completely developed the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.”

sn47.28:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā sāriputto āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ etadavoca:

sn47.28:1.3.pli: “katamesaṃ, āvuso anuruddha, dhammānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā mahābhiññataṃ patto”ti?
sn47.28:1.3.eng: “Reverend Anuruddha, what things have you developed and cultivated to attain great direct knowledge?”

sn47.28:1.4.pli: “Catunnaṃ, āvuso, satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā mahābhiññataṃ patto.
sn47.28:1.4.eng: “Reverend, I attained great direct knowledge by developing and cultivating the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

sn47.28:2.2.pli: Idhāhaṃ, āvuso, kāye kāyānupassī viharāmi ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.28:2.2.eng: It’s when I meditate observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.28:2.3.eng: I meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.28:2.5.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharāmi ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.28:2.5.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.28:2.6.pli: Imesaṃ khvāhaṃ, āvuso, catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā mahābhiññataṃ patto.
sn47.28:2.6.eng: I attained great direct knowledge by developing and cultivating these four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

sn47.28:2.7.pli: Imesañca panāhaṃ, āvuso, catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā sahassaṃ lokaṃ abhijānāmī”ti.
sn47.28:2.7.eng: And it’s because of developing and cultivating these four kinds of mindfulness meditation that I directly know the thousandfold galaxy.”

sn47.29:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā ānando rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
sn47.29:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Ānanda was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

sn47.29:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sirivaḍḍho gahapati ābādhiko hoti dukkhito bāḷhagilāno.
sn47.29:1.2.eng: Now at that time the householder Sirivaḍḍha was sick, suffering, gravely ill.

sn47.29:1.3.pli: Atha kho sirivaḍḍho gahapati aññataraṃ purisaṃ āmantesi:

sn47.29:1.4.pli: “ehi tvaṃ, ambho purisa, yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā mama vacanena āyasmato ānandassa pāde sirasā vanda:
sn47.29:1.4.eng: “Please, worthy man, go to Venerable Ānanda, and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Say to him:

sn47.29:1.5.eng: ‘Sir, the householder Sirivaḍḍha is sick, suffering, gravely ill.

sn47.29:1.6.pli: So āyasmato ānandassa pāde sirasā vandatī’ti.
sn47.29:1.6.eng: He bows with his head to your feet.’

sn47.29:1.8.pli: ‘sādhu kira, bhante, āyasmā ānando yena sirivaḍḍhassa gahapatissa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā’”ti.
sn47.29:1.8.eng: ‘Sir, please visit him at his home out of sympathy.’”

sn47.29:1.9.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho so puriso sirivaḍḍhassa gahapatissa paṭissutvā yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so puriso āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca:
sn47.29:1.9.eng: “Yes, sir,” that man replied. He did as Sirivaḍḍha asked.

sn47.29:1.10.pli: “sirivaḍḍho, bhante, gahapati ābādhiko dukkhito bāḷhagilāno, so āyasmato ānandassa pāde sirasā vandati.

sn47.29:1.12.pli: ‘sādhu kira, bhante, āyasmā ānando yena sirivaḍḍhassa gahapatissa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā’”ti.

sn47.29:2.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena sirivaḍḍhassa gahapatissa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi. Nisajja kho āyasmā ānando sirivaḍḍhaṃ gahapatiṃ etadavoca:
sn47.29:2.1.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the home of the householder Sirivaḍḍha, sat down on the seat spread out, and said to him:

sn47.29:2.2.pli: “kacci te, gahapati, khamanīyaṃ kacci yāpanīyaṃ, kacci dukkhā vedanā paṭikkamanti, no abhikkamanti; paṭikkamosānaṃ paññāyati, no abhikkamo”ti?
sn47.29:2.2.eng: “I hope you’re keeping well, householder; I hope you’re all right. And I hope the pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.”

sn47.29:2.3.pli: “Na me, bhante, khamanīyaṃ na yāpanīyaṃ. Bāḷhā me dukkhā vedanā abhikkamanti, no paṭikkamanti; abhikkamosānaṃ paññāyati, no paṭikkamo”ti.
sn47.29:2.3.eng: “Sir, I’m not keeping well, I’m not getting by. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing is evident, not its fading.”

sn47.29:3.2.pli: ‘kāye kāyānupassī viharissāmi ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.29:3.2.eng: ‘I’ll meditate observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.29:3.3.eng: I’ll meditate on an aspect of feelings …

sn47.29:3.5.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharissāmi ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassan’ti.
sn47.29:3.5.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.’

sn47.29:4.1.pli: “Yeme, bhante, bhagavatā cattāro satipaṭṭhānā desitā saṃvijjanti, te dhammā mayi, ahañca tesu dhammesu sandissāmi.
sn47.29:4.1.eng: “These four kinds of mindfulness meditation that were taught by the Buddha are found in me, and I exhibit them.

sn47.29:4.2.pli: Ahañhi, bhante, kāye kāyānupassī viharāmi ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.29:4.2.eng: For I meditate observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.29:4.3.eng: I meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.29:4.5.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharāmi ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.29:4.5.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.29:4.6.pli: Yāni cimāni, bhante, bhagavatā pañcorambhāgiyāni saṃyojanāni desitāni, nāhaṃ, bhante, tesaṃ kiñci attani appahīnaṃ samanupassāmī”ti.
sn47.29:4.6.eng: And of the five lower fetters taught by the Buddha, I don’t see any that I haven’t given up.”

sn47.29:4.8.eng: You have declared the fruit of non-return.”

sn47.3:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn47.3:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn47.3:1.2.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn47.3:1.2.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

sn47.3:1.3.pli: “sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā saṅkhittena dhammaṃ desetu, yamahaṃ bhagavato dhammaṃ sutvā eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto vihareyyan”ti.
sn47.3:1.3.eng: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”

sn47.3:1.4.pli: “Evameva panidhekacce moghapurisā mañceva ajjhesanti, dhamme ca bhāsite mameva anubandhitabbaṃ maññantī”ti.
sn47.3:1.4.eng: “This is exactly how some futile people ask me for something. But when the teaching has been explained they think only of following me around.”

sn47.3:1.5.pli: “Desetu me, bhante, bhagavā saṅkhittena dhammaṃ, desetu sugato saṅkhittena dhammaṃ. Appeva nāmāhaṃ bhagavato bhāsitassa atthaṃ jāneyyaṃ, appeva nāmāhaṃ bhagavato bhāsitassa dāyādo assan”ti.
sn47.3:1.5.eng: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief! May the Holy One teach me the Dhamma in brief! Hopefully I can understand the meaning of what the Buddha says! Hopefully I can be an heir of the Buddha’s teaching!”

sn47.3:1.6.pli: “Tasmātiha tvaṃ, bhikkhu, ādimeva visodhehi kusalesu dhammesu.
sn47.3:1.6.eng: “Well then, mendicant, you should purify the starting point of skillful qualities.

sn47.3:1.7.eng: What is the starting point of skillful qualities?

sn47.3:1.8.eng: Well purified ethics and correct view.

sn47.3:1.9.pli: Yato kho te, bhikkhu, sīlañca suvisuddhaṃ bhavissati diṭṭhi ca ujukā, tato tvaṃ, bhikkhu, sīlaṃ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya cattāro satipaṭṭhāne tividhena bhāveyyāsi.
sn47.3:1.9.eng: When your ethics are well purified and your view is correct, you should develop the four kinds of mindfulness meditation in three ways, depending on and grounded on ethics.

sn47.3:2.2.pli: Idha tvaṃ, bhikkhu, ajjhattaṃ vā kāye kāyānupassī viharāhi ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.3:2.2.eng: Meditate observing an aspect of the body internally—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.3:2.3.pli: bahiddhā vā kāye kāyānupassī viharāhi ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.3:2.3.eng: Or meditate observing an aspect of the body externally—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.3:2.4.pli: ajjhattabahiddhā vā kāye kāyānupassī viharāhi ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.3:2.4.eng: Or meditate observing an aspect of the body internally and externally—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.3:2.5.eng: Or meditate observing an aspect of feelings internally …

sn47.3:2.7.pli: ajjhattabahiddhā vā vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharāhi ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.3:2.7.eng: internally and externally—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.3:2.8.eng: Or meditate observing an aspect of the mind internally …

sn47.3:2.10.pli: ajjhattabahiddhā vā citte cittānupassī viharāhi ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.3:2.10.eng: internally and externally—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.3:2.11.eng: Or meditate observing an aspect of principles internally …

sn47.3:2.13.pli: ajjhattabahiddhā vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharāhi ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.3:2.13.eng: internally and externally—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.3:2.14.pli: Yato kho tvaṃ, bhikkhu, sīlaṃ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya ime cattāro satipaṭṭhāne evaṃ tividhena bhāvessasi, tato tuyhaṃ, bhikkhu, yā ratti vā divaso vā āgamissati vuddhiyeva pāṭikaṅkhā kusalesu dhammesu, no parihānī”ti.
sn47.3:2.14.eng: When you develop the four kinds of mindfulness meditation in these three ways, depending on and grounded on ethics, you can expect growth, not decline, in skillful qualities, whether by day or by night.”

sn47.3:3.1.pli: Atha kho so bhikkhu bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
sn47.3:3.1.eng: And then that mendicant approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.

sn47.3:3.2.pli: Atha kho so bhikkhu eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
sn47.3:3.2.eng: Then that mendicant, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

sn47.3:3.3.pli: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
sn47.3:3.3.eng: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”

sn47.3:3.4.pli: Aññataro ca pana so bhikkhu arahataṃ ahosīti.
sn47.3:3.4.eng: And that mendicant became one of the perfected.

sn47.30:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena mānadinno gahapati ābādhiko hoti dukkhito bāḷhagilāno.
sn47.30:1.2.eng: Now at that time the householder Mānadinna was sick, suffering, gravely ill.

sn47.30:1.3.pli: Atha kho mānadinno gahapati aññataraṃ purisaṃ āmantesi:

sn47.30:1.4.eng: “Please, worthy man, go to Venerable Ānanda …” …

sn47.30:1.5.pli: na me, bhante, khamanīyaṃ na yāpanīyaṃ. Bāḷhā me dukkhā vedanā abhikkamanti, no paṭikkamanti; abhikkamosānaṃ paññāyati, no paṭikkamoti.
sn47.30:1.5.eng: “Sir, I’m not keeping well, I’m not getting by. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing is evident, not its fading.

sn47.30:1.6.pli: Evarūpāya cāhaṃ, bhante, dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno kāye kāyānupassī viharāmi ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.30:1.6.eng: When I experience such painful feelings I meditate observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.30:1.7.eng: I meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.30:1.9.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharāmi ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.30:1.9.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.30:1.10.pli: Yāni cimāni, bhante, bhagavatā pañcorambhāgiyāni saṃyojanāni desitāni, nāhaṃ, bhante, tesaṃ kiñci attani appahīnaṃ samanupassāmī”ti.
sn47.30:1.10.eng: And of the five lower fetters taught by the Buddha, I don’t see any that I haven’t given up.”

sn47.30:1.12.eng: You have declared the fruit of non-return.”

sn47.31:1.2.pli: “‘Ayaṃ kāye kāyānupassanā’ti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi, ñāṇaṃ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
sn47.31:1.2.eng: “‘This is the observation of an aspect of the body.’ Such, mendicants, was the vision, knowledge, wisdom, realization, and light that arose in me regarding teachings not learned before from another.

sn47.31:1.3.pli: ‘Sā kho panāyaṃ kāye kāyānupassanā bhāvetabbā’ti me, bhikkhave …pe…
sn47.31:1.3.eng: ‘This observation of an aspect of the body should be developed.’ …

sn47.31:1.4.pli: bhāvitā’ti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi, ñāṇaṃ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
sn47.31:1.4.eng: ‘This observation of an aspect of the body has been developed.’ Such was the vision, knowledge, wisdom, realization, and light that arose in me regarding teachings not learned before from another.

sn47.31:2.1.pli: ‘Ayaṃ vedanāsu vedanānupassanā’ti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi, ñāṇaṃ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
sn47.31:2.1.eng: ‘This is the observation of an aspect of feelings.’ …

sn47.31:2.2.pli: ‘Sā kho panāyaṃ vedanāsu vedanānupassanā bhāvetabbā’ti me, bhikkhave …pe…
sn47.31:2.2.eng: ‘This observation of an aspect of feelings should be developed.’ …

sn47.31:2.3.pli: bhāvitā’ti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi, ñāṇaṃ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
sn47.31:2.3.eng: ‘This observation of an aspect of feelings has been developed.’ …

sn47.31:3.1.pli: ‘Ayaṃ citte cittānupassanā’ti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi, ñāṇaṃ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
sn47.31:3.1.eng: ‘This is the observation of an aspect of the mind.’ …

sn47.31:3.2.pli: ‘Sā kho panāyaṃ citte cittānupassanā bhāvetabbā’ti me, bhikkhave …pe…
sn47.31:3.2.eng: ‘This observation of an aspect of the mind should be developed.’ …

sn47.31:3.3.pli: bhāvitā’ti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi, ñāṇaṃ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
sn47.31:3.3.eng: ‘This observation of an aspect of the mind has been developed.’ …

sn47.31:4.1.pli: ‘Ayaṃ dhammesu dhammānupassanā’ti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi, ñāṇaṃ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
sn47.31:4.1.eng: ‘This is the observation of an aspect of principles.’ …

sn47.31:4.2.pli: ‘Sā kho panāyaṃ dhammesu dhammānupassanā bhāvetabbā’ti me, bhikkhave …pe…
sn47.31:4.2.eng: ‘This observation of an aspect of principles should be developed.’ …

sn47.31:4.3.pli: bhāvitā’ti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi, ñāṇaṃ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādī”ti.
sn47.31:4.3.eng: ‘This observation of an aspect of principles has been developed.’ Such was the vision, knowledge, wisdom, realization, and light that arose in me regarding teachings not learned before from another.”

sn47.32:1.1.pli: “Cattārome, bhikkhave, satipaṭṭhānā bhāvitā bahulīkatā ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattanti.
sn47.32:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these four kinds of mindfulness meditation, when developed and cultivated, lead solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

sn47.32:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.32:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.32:2.3.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.32:2.5.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.32:2.5.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.32:2.6.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvitā bahulīkatā ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattantī”ti.
sn47.32:2.6.eng: These four kinds of mindfulness meditation, when developed and cultivated, lead solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.”

sn47.33:1.1.pli: “Yesaṃ kesañci, bhikkhave, cattāro satipaṭṭhānā viraddhā, viraddho tesaṃ ariyo maggo sammā dukkhakkhayagāmī.
sn47.33:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, whoever has missed out on the four kinds of mindfulness meditation has missed out on the noble path to the complete ending of suffering.

sn47.33:1.2.pli: Yesaṃ kesañci, bhikkhave, cattāro satipaṭṭhānā āraddhā, āraddho tesaṃ ariyo maggo sammā dukkhakkhayagāmī.
sn47.33:1.2.eng: Whoever has undertaken the four kinds of mindfulness meditation has undertaken the noble path to the complete ending of suffering.

sn47.33:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.33:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.33:2.3.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.33:2.5.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.33:2.5.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.33:2.6.pli: Yesaṃ kesañci, bhikkhave, ime cattāro satipaṭṭhānā viraddhā, viraddho tesaṃ ariyo maggo sammā dukkhakkhayagāmī.
sn47.33:2.6.eng: Whoever has missed out on these four kinds of mindfulness meditation has missed out on the noble path to the complete ending of suffering.

sn47.33:2.7.pli: Yesaṃ kesañci, bhikkhave, ime cattāro satipaṭṭhānā āraddhā, āraddho tesaṃ ariyo maggo sammā dukkhakkhayagāmī”ti.
sn47.33:2.7.eng: Whoever has undertaken these four kinds of mindfulness meditation has undertaken the noble path to the complete ending of suffering.”

sn47.34:1.1.pli: “Cattārome, bhikkhave, satipaṭṭhānā bhāvitā bahulīkatā apārā pāraṃ gamanāya saṃvattanti.
sn47.34:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when these four kinds of mindfulness meditation are developed and cultivated they lead to going from the near shore to the far shore.

sn47.34:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.34:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.34:2.3.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.34:2.5.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.34:2.5.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.34:2.6.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvitā bahulīkatā apārā pāraṃ gamanāya saṃvattantī”ti.
sn47.34:2.6.eng: When these four kinds of mindfulness meditation are developed and cultivated they lead to going from the near shore to the far shore.”

sn47.35:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant should live mindful and aware.

sn47.35:1.3.eng: This is my instruction to you.

sn47.35:2.1.eng: And how is a mendicant mindful?

sn47.35:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.35:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.35:2.3.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.35:2.5.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.35:2.5.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.35:2.6.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sato hoti.
sn47.35:2.6.eng: That’s how a mendicant is mindful.

sn47.35:3.1.eng: And how is a mendicant aware?

sn47.35:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno viditā vedanā uppajjanti, viditā upaṭṭhahanti, viditā abbhatthaṃ gacchanti.
sn47.35:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant knows feelings as they arise, as they remain, and as they go away.

sn47.35:3.3.pli: Viditā vitakkā uppajjanti, viditā upaṭṭhahanti, viditā abbhatthaṃ gacchanti.
sn47.35:3.3.eng: They know thoughts as they arise, as they remain, and as they go away.

sn47.35:3.4.pli: Viditā saññā uppajjanti, viditā upaṭṭhahanti, viditā abbhatthaṃ gacchanti.
sn47.35:3.4.eng: They know perceptions as they arise, as they remain, and as they go away.

sn47.35:3.5.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sampajāno hoti.
sn47.35:3.5.eng: That’s how a mendicant is aware.

sn47.35:3.6.eng: A mendicant should live mindful and aware.

sn47.35:3.7.eng: This is my instruction to you.”

sn47.36:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

sn47.36:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.36:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.36:1.4.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.36:1.6.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.36:1.6.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.36:1.7.eng: These are the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

sn47.36:1.8.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā dvinnaṃ phalānaṃ aññataraṃ phalaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—
sn47.36:1.8.eng: Because of developing and cultivating these four kinds of mindfulness meditation, one of two results can be expected:

sn47.36:1.9.pli: diṭṭheva dhamme aññā, sati vā upādisese anāgāmitā”ti.
sn47.36:1.9.eng: enlightenment in this very life, or if there’s something left over, non-return.”

sn47.37:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

sn47.37:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.37:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.37:1.4.pli: Tassa kāye kāyānupassino viharato yo kāyasmiṃ chando so pahīyati.
sn47.37:1.4.eng: As they do so they give up desire for the body.

sn47.37:1.5.eng: When desire is given up they realize freedom from death.

sn47.37:2.1.pli: Vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.37:2.1.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.37:2.2.pli: Tassa vedanāsu vedanānupassino viharato yo vedanāsu chando so pahīyati.
sn47.37:2.2.eng: As they do so they give up desire for feelings.

sn47.37:2.3.eng: When desire is given up they realize freedom from death.

sn47.37:3.1.pli: Citte cittānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.37:3.1.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of the mind—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.37:3.2.pli: Tassa citte cittānupassino viharato yo cittamhi chando so pahīyati.
sn47.37:3.2.eng: As they do so they give up desire for the mind.

sn47.37:3.3.eng: When desire is given up they realize freedom from death.

sn47.37:4.1.pli: Dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.37:4.1.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.37:4.2.pli: Tassa dhammesu dhammānupassino viharato yo dhammesu chando so pahīyati.
sn47.37:4.2.eng: As they do so they give up desire for principles.

sn47.37:4.3.eng: When desire is given up they realize freedom from death.”

sn47.38:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

sn47.38:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.38:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.38:1.4.pli: Tassa kāye kāyānupassino viharato kāyo pariññāto hoti.
sn47.38:1.4.eng: As they do so they completely understand the body.

sn47.38:1.5.eng: When the body is completely understood they realize freedom from death.

sn47.38:2.1.pli: Vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.38:2.1.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.38:2.2.pli: Tassa vedanāsu vedanānupassino viharato vedanā pariññātā honti.
sn47.38:2.2.eng: As they do so they completely understand feelings.

sn47.38:2.3.eng: When feelings are completely understood they realize freedom from death.

sn47.38:3.1.pli: Citte cittānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.38:3.1.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of the mind—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.38:3.2.pli: Tassa citte cittānupassino viharato cittaṃ pariññātaṃ hoti.
sn47.38:3.2.eng: As they do so they completely understand the mind.

sn47.38:3.3.eng: When the mind is completely understood they realize freedom from death.

sn47.38:4.1.pli: Dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.38:4.1.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.38:4.2.pli: Tassa dhammesu dhammānupassino viharato dhammā pariññātā honti.
sn47.38:4.2.eng: As they do so they completely understand principles.

sn47.38:4.3.eng: When principles are completely understood they realize freedom from death.”
